title: Feature Engineering
text:
1. Creating Time-Based Features
Tourism data is strongly seasonal. Time features help models learn recurring patterns. Examples include:

Month, Quarter, Year
Day of the week (useful for high-frequency data)
Season indicators (e.g., summer/winter tourism peaks)
Holiday periods, such as Christmas or national holidays

title: Feature Engineering
text:
2. Lag Features
These capture how the number of tourists in previous periods influences future values. Examples:

Tourists lagged by 1 month
Lag 3, lag 6, lag 12 (to capture annual seasonality)

title: Feature Engineering
text:
3. Rolling Window Statistics
Rolling features smooth fluctuations and describe recent trends. Examples:

3-month moving average
12-month rolling sum (useful for year-over-year analysis)
Rolling standard deviation (volatility of tourism flows)

title: Feature Engineering
text:
4. Pandemic / Shock Indicators
Tourism is highly sensitive to global shocks. Examples:

COVID-19 lockdown periods
Political instability indicators
Natural disaster events

title: Feature Engineering
text:
5. Interaction Features
Interactions help models understand combined effects, such as: “Summer season” × “Low exchange rate”.

title: WP9 S2 Tourist accommodation establishments
text: Pilot study for imputation - accommodation establishments

title: WP9 S2 Tourist accommodation establishments
text:
Type of accomodation establisments
Tourist accommodation establishments regardless of the type, owner, and location, as well as establishments with other purposes (not related to tourism) that are temporarily used by tourists (e.g., student dormitories, sports and recreation centers).
Tourist accommodation establishments classified into the following activity groups according to NACE Rev. 2 classification:

55.1 – hotels and similar accommodation,
55.2 – holiday and other short-stay accommodation,
55.3 – camping grounds, recreational vehicle parks and trailer parks. The study covers 20 types of tourist accommodation establishments.

title: WP9 S2 Tourist accommodation establishments
text:
About survey
KT-1: Report on the occupancy of tourist accommodation establishments:

Mandatory monthly survey of accommodation establishments with 10 or more bed-places.
Census survey of 14,859 establishments.
The deadline for submitting reports is the 10th day after the reporting month. In practice, establishments report throughout the entire month.
Unit response rate is approximately 80% and varies due to seasonality.
Item non-response pertains mostly to foreign tourist data.

title: WP9 S2 Tourist accommodation establishments
text:
About Data
Range of collected data

Establishment name, type, address and category of establishment
Months of operation
Rooms and bed places
Occupancy (tourists and nights spent) during the surveyed month
Occupancy (tourists and nights spent) by foreign tourists with respect to country of residence
Categorical and count data

Notice 
This repository had been created from AIML4OS template. If you want to use it see this tutorial.

title: A basic chapter
text:
A beautiful dataframe
This section demonstrates how to create and display a simple pandas DataFrame.


Code
import pandas as pd

data = {
    "Name": ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"],
    "Age": [25, 30, 35],
    "City": ["Paris", "Dublin", "Berlin"]
}

df = pd.DataFrame(data)
df

title: A basic chapter
text:
A more sophisticated table
This section demonstrates how to create and display a simple pandas DataFrame.


Code
from great_tables import GT, html
from great_tables.data import sza
import polars as pl
from polars import col as c
import polars.selectors as cs

sza_pivot = (
    pl.from_pandas(sza)
    .filter((c.latitude == "20") & (c.tst <= "1200"))
    .select(pl.col("*").exclude("latitude"))
    .drop_nulls()
    .pivot(values="sza", index="month", on="tst", sort_columns=True)
)

(
    GT(sza_pivot, rowname_col="month")
    .data_color(
        domain=[90, 0],
        palette=["rebeccapurple", "white", "orange"],
        na_color="white",
    )
    .tab_header(
        title="Solar Zenith Angles from 05:30 to 12:00",
        subtitle=html("Average monthly values at latitude of 20°N."),
    )
    .sub_missing(missing_text="")
)
